sections.summary: Allah affirms that His command is imminent and highlights His creation of the heavens, earth, and **humanity** from fluid. He provided **livestock** for human warmth, food, and transport, emphasizing that while paths may be flawed, He alone points to the straight way.

Natural blessings such as rain, vegetation, and the sea serve as proofs of **Tawhid** and the regulation of the universe by divine command. These signs contrast the creative power of Allah with the helplessness of **idols**, which are created and unable to resurrect or create anything.

Those who reject the Hereafter are identified as **arrogant**, dismissing divine revelation as ancient legends and bearing their own sins on the Day of Resurrection. In contrast, the **pious** are welcomed into the Gardens of Perpetuity with peace, rewarded for their **wholesome state** and righteous conduct.

Messengers were sent to every community to enjoin the worship of Allah and the avoidance of **idolatry**, serving only as deliverers of clear communication. The text affirms that the **resurrection** is a binding promise to clarify human differences and that those who scheme evil will not escape divine retribution.

All created things, including their **shadows**, prostrate to Allah in total humility and fear of their Lord. This range rebukes those who attribute partners to Allah and condemns the pagan practice of grieving over **female infants** in humiliation.

Lessons are provided through the production of milk in cattle and the navigation of the **bee**, which is inspired to produce honey as a **healing** for people. Allah created the human being and controls the return to the **worst age** of life after the acquisition of knowledge.

Allah distributed **livelihood** in varying ranks and granted humans the hearing, sight, and brains necessary for **gratitude**. He established homes as places of rest and provided portable **dwellings** from livestock hides to comfort the human being during travel.

On the Day of Judgment, a **witness** will be raised from every community to testify against disbelievers, who will find no rescue. The Quran is established as an **explanation of all things**, providing guidance, mercy, and good news for those who submit.

Allah commands **justice**, goodness, and the fulfillment of **covenants** while forbidding immorality and oppression. Believers are urged to maintain the integrity of their oaths and are reminded that **Satan** has no authority over those who trust in their Lord.

The Quran is revealed through the **Holy Spirit** in a clear **Arabic tongue** to provide stability and guidance for the faithful. A severe warning is issued against those who choose **disbelief** over faith, while mercy is promised to those who emigrate and persevere after being persecuted.

Dietary restrictions are set on **carrion and swine**, and a secure town is cited as an example of how ingratitude leads to hunger and fear. Abraham is honored as an exemplary **monotheist** who was thankful for divine grace, and the text clarifies that the Sabbath was decreed only for those who differed.

The Messenger is instructed to invite others to the way of the Lord with **wisdom** and to practice **patience** in the face of adversity. The surah concludes by noting that Allah is with the **righteous** and those who act with virtue.
